title: Poppins promises favourite film magic tricks in live show
text:
Poppins promises favourite film magic tricks in live show Last updated 09:45, February 24 2017 PHOTO: ROBYN ATKENSON 
The cast of Mary Poppins warms up for opening night with a sneak preview on the streets of Napier. Laura Jeffares, centre, plays Mary Poppins 
There will be a flying nanny and dancing on the ceiling in Hawke's Bay this March. 
Napier Operatic Society is bringing Mary Poppins to the region in the most technically demanding production the organisation has ever staged, with flying cast members and a massive rotating stage. 
The musical, which runs from March 10 to 25 at the Napier Municipal Theatre, follows the same story line as the beloved film and book. PHOTO: MEGAN HUNT/FAIRFAX NZ 
Yvonne Arrowsmith and Bev Carroll check the fit of a coat for Laura Jeffares who plays Mary Poppins. 
Mary Poppins arrives at the home of the Banks family in London, bringing magic to the lives of the adults and children she encounters. 
READ MORE: 
Stage director Marc Collier said the society was part of a consortium of New Zealand theatre groups which collectively bought the rights to the production then pooled funds to professionally build a set and costumes. 
These pack down into three large shipping containers and will visit 11 theatres in total. 
The Napier society has staged technical performances before, "but not to this degree", Collier said. 
Mary Poppins flies, Bert walks up walls and characters disappear up a chimney. 
"This is specialised stuff, we have riggers coming down from Auckland and approximately $45,000 worth of rigging will be used," he said. 
One of the main pieces of set is a massive five-metre high house which opens like a large dolls house, then rotates. 
"It's moving all the time," Collier said. 
Details and colour are projected onto the white set to allow the backdrop to change and move. 
The house alone takes six people to move during the performance. 
Together with the stage hands, lighting crew, make up and costume team there were at least twice the number of people putting the show together back stage than those performing. 
Preparing the cast started in August with workshops, auditions in September and rehearsals in October for the onstage cast of 56. 
Favourite songs from the film, along with iconic magical tricks will be recreated on stage. "It's going to be a really fun show for people to see." 
With such a big cast even supplying biscuits, tea and coffee for months worth of rehearsals mounted up. 
"It's quite a risk but we love bringing these big shows to Hawke's Bay audiences," Collier said. 
* Children's tickets range from $15, adults from $35 and a family pass for two adults and two children from $85. Book at ticketek.
